metadata.title: Are You on Track? — Communicate Your Strategic Themes on an Interactive Roadmap with No-Code. | by Sebastian Zolg 🤝 | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Are You on Track? — Communicate Your Strategic Themes on an Interactive Roadmap with No-Code.
metadata.description: When it comes to aligning your organization or project team, then there is nothing better than a clear and visually appealing roadmap. Let's build one with Microsoft Power BI and Power Apps.

all_paragraphs: When it comes to aligning your organization or project team, then there is nothing better than a clear and visually appealing roadmap.
So, If you want this Dashboard 👇 then this story is for you!
But wait! There is a problem…

…Roadmaps are commonly the result of collaboration with your team and stakeholders. While we have a bunch of nice tools out there to visualize stuff, we don’t have one that can also manipulate the data on the fly.
With the combination of Microsoft Power BI and Power Apps, we can build such a solution on our own.
The best of it: No coding skills needed!
First, we need a place to store our roadmap data. Usually, this results in setting up yet another database on yet another server.
Luckily the Microsoft Power Platform comes with something called Common Data Service (CDS) which essentially lets you securely store and manage data that can be used by your business applications.
I’ve prepared a set of sample roadmap items to get you started and packed them into a .csv file that you can download from my Github Repository.
Let’s get started and create our Roadmap Items entity in CDS. Make sure you have at least a trial Account for Microsoft Power Apps and Microsoft Power BI to follow along.
Open Power Apps in your browser, open Entities and click Get data.
There are several options on how you can load the data into CDS. We choose to go for Text/CSV.
Upload the Product Roadmap Items.csv from my Github Repository to your OneDrive or copy the URL of this gist into the File path textbox and click Next.
Review that the data is loaded correctly and click Next.

Based on our sample data we can now model our Roadmap Items entity. Model it according to the Screenshot below and make sure, you’ve set all Destination field types to Text, except for the Description field, which should stay as Multiline text.
We have the option to periodically refresh the data from its source, but we stick with Refresh manually for now.
Click Create and wait for the process to load your data into CDS.
Back in the Entity view we can search for our newly created Roadmap Items entity and make sure it was created.
That’s it! Our data is now in the cloud and managed by CDS from where we can consume it with any business application we want.
Now that we have our roadmap data in CDS we can easily consume it in Power BI for further ETL.
Open Power BI Desktop and click Get Data.
From the list of available data sources, select the Power Platform and choose Common Data Service. Click Connect to proceed.
Now we have to enter the root URL of our Common Data Service. This one is unique per account, so you have to look it up for yourself first.
In the Power Apps Portal, go to Settings (Gear Icon) > Advanced settings.
Copy the root URL as indicated by the screenshot below. This is the URL of your CDS.
Back in Power BI Desktop, paste the URL into the Server Url field and click OK.
You might be prompted to sign in with your account. Click Connect when you’ve signed it successfully.
If everything goes well you can search for Roadmap in the Navigator. Notice that the name prefix will be different as it is unique per account.
Check the box next to the RoadmapsItems table icon and click Load.
Now that we have the data loaded from our CDS, it’s time to visualize our roadmap. We’re going to use the as Timeline custom Visual from the Power BI Marketplace.
Click on the … icon within the Visualization panel and select Import from marketplace.
Search for as Timeline and click Add.
With the empty as Timeline visual added to our page, we can now drag and drop the necessary fields from our CDS data source to the data panel. Check the screenshot below on which field goes where.
To make it visually more appealing, select the timeline visual, click the Format icon and set the properties as below.
The result is an already quite decent looking timeline build on your CDS data. Good job! Hang tight!

We already have the most important visualization in place, so it is time to go one step further and make our dashboard truly interactive by allowing the data to be changed directly from the dashboard. We achieve this by adding a Power App to our Dashboard.
To do so, click the Power App icon from the Visualizations panel and check xxx_item from the Fields panel. Finally, click Create new inside the Power App visual.
This will fire up the Power App Portal in your browser. Click OK to confirm this redirect.

The newly created Power App already contains a gallery control that we want to get rid of. Click the … icon next to the gallery control and select Delete. This gives us an empty canvas and a lot of space to get our own work done 😎.
From the control ribbon, click Forms > Edit.

Now that we have an empty Edit Form on our canvas, we can connect to the same CDS data source as our Power BI Dashboard. Click the Database Icon and search for Roadmap Items. You should see your CDS entity listed. Click it and it will be added as a data source for your App.
Having the empty Edit Form selected, choose Roadmap Items from the Data Source drop-down list. This will bind the Edit Form to our data source.
Next, we tell the Edit Form which fields we want to display and make available for editing. Click the Edit fields link to open the Fields panel.
Add all necessary fields to the Edit Form by clicking + Add field. You can reorder the fields using drag & drop.
Nice Form! Now that we have a form that can display and edit the values, we need a button to write back the changes to the CDS data source.
Add a Button from the control ribbon, double click it and change the text to Save.
While the new button is selected, choose the OnSelect action from the Formula Bar and paste the formula below.
This formula simply writes back changes to the CDS data source and refreshes the Power BI connection.
Note that there is some limitation for the PowerBIIntegration.Refresh() command which goes beyond this story. You can read it up here.
Next, we need to tell the Edit Form which specific item to display. This information comes directly from Power BI by using the PowerBIIntegration object and its Data property.
The formula below will look up the item from our data source by matching its name against the selected item from our Power BI Dashboard.
Now we have to save our work. Click File.
Select Save as and name the app something like Roadmap Items Editor. Click Save.

Back in our Power BI Report, the Power App visual should have refreshed automatically. Verify it’s working by clicking a single item on the timeline visual and notice how our Edit Form loads the corresponding details.

Alright. Let’s change some data. Click any given item on the timeline and modify it’s starting date and description. Hit the Save button and click Refresh on the control ribbon to watch your timeline update.
That’s it! We have all the functionality we need. Time to make it look sexy and add the famous Dark Theme 🕶.
Back in Power Apps, click Theme and select Dark Yellow.
To match the forthcoming background color of our Power BI Dashboard, set the background of the app to be#333333.
Don’t forget to Save and Publish your Power App again. The change should immediately be reflected on your Power BI Dashboard.
In Power BI Desktop, click Switch Theme from the control ribbon and select the Solar theme.
This gives us the right color palette and we can start tweaking it even more. Below are some settings I recommend.
After adding a few more visuals by drag & drop, your final result should look like below.

Congratulation! You did great and this is a really nice Dashboard that you can now share in various formats. Consider exporting it as PDF, publishing it inside your organization using Power BI or sending out a weekly report to your stakeholders.
Now that we unlocked the combined power of Microsoft Power BI and Power Apps, we can implement even more advanced scenarios.
What about adding a button to export your roadmap item to the Kanban board of any team in your organization working with Trello, Jira or Azure DevOps?
Any other ideas? Have fun trying them out yourself.
